title: What warrants an S rank?

embed.description: Every game is a story; visit the new League of Legends match history to check out how this one ends and share your own!

body:
Reaaally. S for graves... A for me. I really do not understand how the system works. Same wards placed, so its not that. Higher KDA than graves, its not that. Higher damage and kill % damage, not that. More cs/gold, not that. More turrets/inhibs, not that. Dragon maybe? Does walking past and smiting an objective add significantly to this? Maybe it's the 3 more kills, which is ridiculous because I thought it was a team-based game, focused on objectives and not kills as riot has stated over and over.

I'm probably just salty because I actually tried to get a chest this game so I could use one of the 5 keys I have from fragments alone. But I'm really curious why I got such a low champion mastery score compared to everyone else and how the system actually works.

Imgur link for easier visualization:  http://imgur.com/a/fLxQQ

replies.body:
It isn't a set score you need to achieve, it's all relative to how everyone else on the server is doing with the **same champ in the same role**.

From Riot:

> It’s based on the champion and role that you just played in a game. So, for example, we look at Annie mid differently to Annie support. We take a series of performance metrics and compare how you do to all other players in your region in your champion / position combination. It is percentile driven - so earning a high score means** you performed in the top x% of players** on that champ in that position. The grade itself governs the point gains.

[(Source)](http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/page/features/champion-mastery)

[Basically grades similarly to a bell curve](http://study.com/academy/lesson/bell-curve-definition-impact-on-grades.html), meaning we have a server full of really good players. 

**Riot hasn't released a list of the factors that contribute to a high grade,** but I would suggest working on CS, objective assists, and possibly warding to bump up your grade that extra notch ♥

>It’s based on the champion and role that you just played in a game. So, for example, we look at Annie mid differently to Annie support. We take a series of performance metrics and compare how you do to all other players in your region in your champion / position combination. It is percentile driven - so earning a high score means you performed in the top x% of players on that champ in that position. The grade itself governs the point gains.

What would happen if you were the 1st ever person to go a role/champ combo? auto s no matter what?

That's completely ridiculous. My score warrants an A rank apparently. So, if I include the object assists, which was the 2 bottom turrets and one mid, and the 2 dragons. That's half of the map's objectives in turrets (of the destroyed ones I participated in 6/10, Graves would have been in the mid lane 3, he was dead for the final push of the last 2, didn't touch inhibitors and was present for the first dragon, not the second), 2 inhibitors which never re-spawned, and both dragons taken. Ward placement was as soon as it was off CD after level 9 as you can see, you hold yellow trinket most of the time to stop people resetting creep aggro in lane. CS was the only thing lacking and was due to rotating and taking said objectives from the kill lead like any good player would.

If we were to follow this reasoning than every S ranked Draven would have over 20kda, taken every tower on the map, bought a sightstone, and not missed one creep in lane. I believe the system should be based on individual performance, and even in this case it is soooooo hard to believe that this is a slightly above average game for a Draven.
